awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A GREEN PROCESS FOR LOW-COST PRODUCTION OF SILICON CARBIDE FROM WASTE SILICON
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop and commercialize a new technology for production of a high-purity silicon carbide powder – a critical feedstock for the semiconductors used in electric vehicles, 5G communication equipment, automobiles, aerospace, etc. - at significantly lower production cost and 75% decreased environmental footprint.  Currently silicon carbide powder is generally imported and is not made in an environmentally sustainable fashion. The proposed project advances a new manufacturing process for the domestic silicon carbide market, estimated to grow from $150 million in 2016 to $500 million in 2027. 

This project advances a process to react silicon powder with a hydrocarbon gas under highly controlled temperature/residence time conditions to produce a pure, crystalline silicon carbide powder. This project develops a sequential two-step process consisting of catalytic pyrolysis of hydrocarbon gas (silicon powder acting as a catalyst) to produce highly active carbon, which subsequently reacts with fine Si powder to form high-purity beta silicon carbide for conversion into alpha silicon carbide with conventional sintering methods.  The objective is to produce 50 g of high purity and fine particle size silicon carbide in one step for industrial evaluation, exploring reaction kinetics, gas solid contacting, optimization of yield and product purity of silicon carbide, as well as process design and technoeconomic analysis for translation at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Susteon silicon carbide (SiC) synthesis technology involves a reaction of fine waste silicon (Si) metal particles with a hydrocarbon stream (e.g. natural gas) in a high-temperature reactor. SiC is a versatile non-oxide ceramic that has a wide range of applications in material and semiconductor manufacturing due to its unique physical and chemical properties include a relatively low thermal expansion, high force-to-weight radius, high thermal conductivity, hardness, resistance to abrasion and corrosion, and most importantly, sustained elastic resistance at temperatures up to 1650°C. In this process, Si particles serve a dual function of catalyzing the pyrolysis of the hydrocarbon feed gas to produce solid carbon and hydrogen gas and the synthesis of SiC.

 

The project work consisted of screening operating conditions that included varying the duration and temperatures of the pyrolysis and SiC synthesis, building and testing a bench-scale reactor design for the SiC synthesis, verifying results with repeated testing, and completing an initial economic assessment based on the project results. All project tasks were completed with promising initial economic findings. The project technical outcomes include:

  • Discovery of operating conditions that achieves: 
    • >99% conversion of Si to SiC
    • High purity hydrogen (H2) production from natural gas – achieving near thermodynamic equilibrium concentration of H2at operating temperature. 
    • No observable SiC particle agglomeration which reduces downstream solids processing cost.
  • Demonstration of proof of concept SiC synthesis reactor prototype verifying Si to SiC conversions and H2 production at the bench scale. 
  • Economic assessment of SiC synthesis process based on bench and lab test results showing <$10/kg SiC production cost is achievable with this technology with >90% less CO2 emissions compared to conventional Acheson process.

Initial economic assessment shows the potential of the process to produce nearly carbon-emissions-free SiC from recycled waste, though additional work can be performed to optimize the operating conditions. Based on the reactor design, the goal of producing green ( phase) SiC is achievable for <$10/kg, which was the target of the Phase I work. Future work can focus on optimizing the operating conditions to further reduce the cost of manufacturing the SiC, scaling the bench unit design to a larger prototype system, and consideration of downstream purification and processing methods to increase the value of the SiC product. 

The Phase I work supported the training and mentorship of graduate students across two institutions allowing them to further develop their research skills and provide experience in process development. If successfully developed, the SiC produced from this process represents a new pathway for cost-effective and domestic manufacturing of carbon-free, low emissions SiC in an environmentally sustainable manner with recycled waste materials.
